tit.e: Shugendo (a term related to religions in Japan))
Shugendo (a term relating to religions in Japan)
Shugendo (a term relating to religions in Japan)

sen.j: 修験道（しゅげんどう）とは、山へ籠もって厳しい修行を行う事により、様々な「験」（しるし）を得る事を目的とする日本独特の混淆宗教である。
sen.e: Shugendo is a Japan-specific Konko-shukyo (a religion combining Buddhism, Shintoism and other religions) whose objective is to do ascetic practice while confining oneself in mountains, in order to obtain various evidences indicating that some practice levels are reached.

Shugendo is a Japan-specific Konko-shukyo (a religion combining Buddhism, Shintoism and other religions) whose objective is to do ascetic practice while confining oneself in the mountains, in order to obtain various shirushi (evidence) which indicate that certain practice levels have been reached.

Shugendo is a Japan-specific Konko-shukyo (a religion combining Buddhism, Shintoism and other religions) whose objective is to do ascetic practice while confining oneself in the mountains, in order to obtain various shirushi (evidence) which indicate that certain practice levels have been reached.

sen.j: 修験道の実践者を修験者または山伏という。
sen.e: The person who does shugendo practice is called a shugensha or yamabushi.
The person who does shugendo practice is called a shugensha or yamabushi.
The person who does shugendo practice is called a shugensha or yamabushi.

sen.j: 森羅万象に命や神霊が宿るとする、古神道の一つである神奈備（かむなび）や磐座（いわくら）という山岳信仰と仏教、道教、陰陽道などが習合して確立した日本独特の宗教である。
sen.e: It is a Japan-specific religion combining various religions, such as Buddhism, Taoism, Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), and Kannabi (an old shintoism) and Iwakura (a mountain worship) in which a life or divine spirit was considered to reside in everything.

It is a Japan-specific religion combining various religions, such as Buddhism, Taoism, Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang, an occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), Kannabi (an old form of Shintoism) and Iwakura (a form of mountain worship) in which a life or divine spirit is considered to reside in everything.

It is a Japan-specific religion combining various religions, such as Buddhism, Taoism, Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang, an occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) with Kannabi (an old form of Shintoism) and Iwakura (a form of mountain worship) in which a life or divine spirit is considered to reside in everything.

sen.j: 奈良時代に成立したとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Shugendo was established in around the Nara period.
It is said that Shugendo was established in the Nara Period.
It is said that Shugendo was established in the Nara Period.

sen.j: 開祖は役行者（役小角）とされる。
sen.e: It is said that EN no Gyoja (EN no Ozunu) founded it.
It is said that EN no Gyoja (EN no Ozunu) was its founder.
It is said that EN no Gyoja (EN no Ozunu) was its founder.

sen.j: 平安時代ごろから盛んに信仰されるようになった。
sen.e: It became to be worshipped widely from around the Heian period.
It came to be widely practised from around the Heian Period.
It came to be widely practiced from around the Heian Period.

sen.j: 平安初期に伝来した密教との結びつきが強く、鎌倉時代後期から南北朝時代 (日本)には独自の立場を確立した。
sen.e: This religion became strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism that was brought o Japan in the early Heian period, and in the era from the latter half of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (in Japan), established its unique position.

This religion became strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism that was brought to Japan in the early Heian Period, and in the era from the latter half of the Kamakura Period to the Period of the Northern and Southern Courts (in Japan), its unique position was established.

This religion became strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism that was brought to Japan in the early Heian Period, and in the era from the latter half of the Kamakura Period to the Period of the Northern and Southern Courts (in Japan), its unique position was established.

sen.j: 密教との関係が強かったことから、仏教の一派とされることもある。
sen.e: Being strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism, it is sometimes considered a sect of Buddhism.
Being strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism, it is sometimes considered a sect of Buddhism.
Being strongly connected to Esoteric Buddhism, it is sometimes considered a sect of Buddhism.

sen.j: 江戸幕府は，慶長十八年（1613）に修験道法度を定め，真言宗系の当山派と、天台宗系の本山派のどちらかに属さねばならないことにした。
sen.e: The Edo bakufu established Shugendo Hatto (Shugendo Law) in 1613, making it a rule that Shugendo had to belong either to the Tozan school related to the Shingon sect or to the Honzan school related to the Tendai sect.

The Edo bakufu established Shugendo Hatto (Shugendo Law) in 1613, making it a rule that Shugendo had to belong either to the Tozan school related to the Shingon sect or to the Honzan school related to the Tendai sect.

The Edo bakufu established Shugendo Hatto (Shugendo Law) in 1613, making it a rule that Shugendo had to belong either to the Tozan school related to the Shingonshu sect or to the Honzan school related to the Tendaishu sect.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）の神仏分離令に続き、明治5年、修験禁止令が出され、修験道は禁止された。
sen.e: Following the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in 1868, the law to ban Shugendo was enforced, prohibiting doing the Shudendo practice.
Following the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in 1868, a law banning Shugendo was introduced, prohibiting Shudendo practice.
Following the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in 1868, a law banning Shugendo was introduced, prohibiting Shugendo practice.

sen.j: また廃仏毀釈により関係する物などが破壊された。
sen.e: In addition, due to Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism), things related to Shugendo were destroyed.
In addition, due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism), things related to Shugendo were destroyed.
In addition, due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism), things related to Shugendo were destroyed.

sen.j: 修験系の講団体のなかには、明治以降、仏教色を薄めて教派神道となったものもある。
sen.e: Making their Buddhist characteristics diminish in the Meiji period and later, some of Shugendo-related religious associations of lay believers became to belong to Sect Shinto.
Attempting to diminish their Buddhist characteristics in the Meiji Period and after, some Shugendo-related religious associations of lay believers came to belong to Sect Shinto.
Attempting to diminish their Buddhist characteristics in the Meiji Period and after, some Shugendo-related religious associations of lay believers came to belong to Sect Shinto.

sen.j: 御嶽教、扶桑教、実行教、丸山教などが主で、不動尊の真言や般若心経の読誦など神仏習合時代の名残も見られる。
sen.e: Major of these Shinto sects were Ontake-kyo, Fuso-Kyo, Jikko-Kyo, and Maruyama-Kyo, and some remains in the period when Buddhism and Shintoism were syncretized, such as chanting of mantras of Fudo-son and chanting of Hannya Shingyo (Heart Sutra), are still observed.

These Shinto sects were mainly Ontake-kyo, Fuso-Kyo, Jikko-Kyo, and Maruyama-Kyo, and some remnants from the period when Buddhism and Shintoism were syncretized, such as the chanting of mantras of Fudo-son and chanting of Hannya Shingyo (Heart Sutra), are still observed.

These Shinto sects were mainly Ontake-kyo, Fuso-Kyo, Jikko-Kyo, and Maruyama-Kyo, and some remnants from the period when Buddhism and Shintoism were syncretized, such as the chanting of mantras of Fudo-son and chanting of Hannya Shingyo (Heart Sutra), are still observed.

sen.j: 修験道の法流は、大きく分けて真言宗系の当山派と、天台宗系の本山派に分類される。
sen.e: The systems of Shugendo teachings are largely classified into the Tozan school related to the Shingon sect and the Honzan school related to the Tendai sect.
The systems of Shugendo teaching are largely classified into the Tozan school related to the Shingon sect and the Honzan school related to the Tendai sect.
The systems of Shugendo teaching are largely classified into the Tozan school related to the Shingonshu sect and the Honzan school related to the Tendaishu sect.

sen.j: 当山派は醍醐寺三宝院を開いた聖宝理源大師に端を発し、本山派は園城寺の増誉が聖護院を建立して熊野三所権現を祭ってから一派として形成されていった。
sen.e: The Tozan school originated in Shobo Rigen Daishi (a Shingon priest who lived in early Heian period) who established Sanbo-in of Daigo-ji Temple, and the Honzan school became formed after Zoyo at Onjo-ji Temple built Shogoin Temple and enshrined there Sansho Gongen (three deities) of Kumano.

The Tozan school was founded by Shobo Rigen Daishi (a Shingon priest who lived in the early Heian Period) who established Sanbo-in at Daigo-ji Temple, and the Honzan school came to be formed after Zoyo at Onjo-ji Temple built Shogoin Temple and enshrined the Sansho Gongen (three deities) of Kumano there.

The Tozan school was founded by Shobo Rigen Daishi (a Shingon priest who lived in the early Heian Period) who established Sanbo-in at Daigo-ji Temple, and the Honzan school came to be formed after Zoyo at Onjo-ji Temple built Shogoin Temple and enshrined the Sansho Gongen (three deities) of Kumano there.

sen.j: 真言や天台は貴族との結びつきが強かった。
sen.e: The Shingon sect and the Tendai sect were strongly connected with nobles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Shingon sect and the Tendai sect were closely linked to the nobility.
The Shingonshu sect and the Tendaishu sect were closely linked to the nobility.

sen.j: しかしながら、修験道においては一般民衆との関わりを持っていた点で、修験者（山伏）の役割は重要であった。
sen.e: However, because Shugendo was related to the general public, roles of Shugensha (yamabushi) were important.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, because Shugendo affected the general public, the roles of Shugensha and yamabushi were important.
However, because Shugendo affected the general public, the roles of Shugensha and yamabushi were important.

sen.j: 奈良県吉野山の金峯山寺（金峰山修験本宗）、京都市左京区の聖護院（本山修験宗）、同伏見区の醍醐寺三宝院（真言宗醍醐派）などを拠点に信仰が行われている。
sen.e: The major worship sites are Kinpusen-ji Temple (the main Shugen sect at Mt. Yoshino) in Mt. Yoshino, Nara Prefecture, Shogoin Temple (Honzan Shugen sect) in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, and Sanbo-in of Daigo-ji Temple (the Daigo school of the Shingon sect) in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

The major sites of worship are Kinpusen-ji Temple (of the main Shugen sect) on Mt. Yoshino, Nara Prefecture, Shogoin Temple (of the Honzan Shugen sect) in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, and Sanbo-in at Daigo-ji Temple (of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect) in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

The major sites of worship are Kinpusen-ji Temple (of the main Shugen sect) on Mt. Yoshino, Nara Prefecture, Shogoin Temple (of the Honzan Shugen sect) in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, and Sanbo-in at Daigo-ji Temple (of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect) in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: また、各地の霊山を拠点とする国峰修験の流れもある。
sen.e: Furthermore, there exist groups related to Kokubu (literally, provincial mountain peaks)-shugen in which sacred mountains in various areas are worshipped.
Furthermore, there exist groups related to Kokubu (literally, provincial mountain peaks) shugen in which sacred mountains in various areas are worshipped.
Furthermore, there exist groups related to Kokubu (literally, provincial mountain peaks) shugen in which sacred mountains in various areas are worshipped.

sen.j: 修験道は神仏習合の信仰であり、日本の神と仏教の神がともに祀られる。
sen.e: Shugendo is a religion in which Shintoism and Buddhism is syncretized, and both gods in Shintoism in Japan and gods in Buddhism are enshrined.
Shugendo is a religion in which Shintoism and Buddhism is syncretized, and both gods of Shintoism and Buddhism are enshrined.
Shugendo is a religion in which Shintoism and Buddhism is syncretized, and both gods of Shintoism and Buddhism are enshrined.

sen.j: 表現形態として、権現（神仏が仮の姿で現れた神）などの神格や王子（参詣途上で儀礼を行う場所）がある。
sen.e: Visible objects for worship include Gongen with divinity (where gongen, a god or Buddha appearing in a temporary shape, is enshrined) and Oji (a place to conduct rituals en route to pilgrimage).
Visible objects for worship include Gongen (where gongen, a god or Buddha appearing in a temporary shape, is enshrined) and Oji (a place to conduct rituals en route to pilgrimage).
Visible objects for worship include Gongen (where gongen, a god or Buddha appearing in a temporary shape, is enshrined) and Oji (a place to conduct rituals en route to pilgrimage).

sen.j: 熊野信仰においては、三所権現・五所王子・四所宮の祭神が重要な位置を占めており、これを勧請した九十九王子が有名である。
sen.e: In Kumano belief, Sansho (three-place) Gongen, Gosho (five-place) Oji, and Yonsho (four-place) Miyano-saishin (enshrined deity of miya (royal person)) occupy important positions, and Kujuku (literally, 99) Oji branched from here are famous.

In the Kumano set of beliefs, Sansho (three-place) Gongen, Gosho (five-place) Oji, and Yonsho (four-place) Miyano-saishin (an enshrined deity of a miya, or royal person) occupy important positions, and the Kujuku (ninety-nine) Oji which stem from here are famous.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity, grammar, word choice.
sen.e: In the Kumano set of beliefs, Sansho (three-place) Gongen, Gosho (five-place) Oji, and Yonsho (four-place) Miyano-saishin (an enshrined deity of a miya, or royal person) occupy important positions, and the Kujuku (ninety-nine) Oji which stem from here are famous.

sen.j: 山伏と関連するため、山に関連した神格が存在することもある。
sen.e: Being related to yamabushi, divinity related to mountains exist in some places.
Being related to yamabushi, divinities connected to mountains exist in some of these places.
Being related to yamabushi, divinities connected to mountains exist in some of these places.

sen.j: 一般的に有名な所では、
sen.e: The following places are famous generally:
The following places are widely known:
The following places are widely known:

sen.j: 蔵王権現（ざおうごんげん）
sen.e: Zao Gongen (the principal image of the Kimpusen Zaodo, and the highest worship object of the Shugendo)
Zao Gongen (the principal image of the Kimpusen Zaodo, and the highest object of worship in Shugendo)
Zao Gongen (the principal image of the Kimpusen Zaodo, and the highest object of worship in Shugendo)

sen.j: 若一王子（にゃくいちおうじ）
sen.e: Nyakuichioji (the first Oji of the Gosho Oji in Kumano)
Nyakuichioji (the first Oji of the Gosho Oji in Kumano)
Nyakuichioji (the first Oji of the Gosho Oji in Kumano)

sen.j: 九十九王子（くじゅうくおうじ）
sen.e: Kujuku Oji (a series of shrines which were established from 12 century to 13 century by the Kumano Shugen priests.)
Kujuku Oji (a series of shrines which were established between the twelfth and thirteenth centuries by the Kumano Shugen priests)
Kujuku Oji (a series of shrines which were established between the twelfth and thirteenth centuries by the Kumano Shugen priests)

sen.j: 前鬼・後鬼（ぜんき・こうき）
sen.e: Zenki Goki (Oni demon in front and the one in back)
Zenki Goki (Oni demon in front and at the back)
sen.cmt: Is this one demon with two faces, or two separate demons?
sen.e: Zenki Goki (Oni demon in front and at the back)

sen.j: 一言主（ひとことぬし）
sen.e: Hitokoto nushi (a god of oracle who says a good thing or a bad thing definitely at one word and is deified as the deity of the Hitokotonushi Shrine of Gose City in Nara Prefecture.)
Hitokoto nushi (an oracle-god who says a good thing or a bad thing clearly in a single word, and is deified as the deity of the Hitokotonushi Shrine of Gose City in Nara Prefecture.)
Hitokoto nushi (an oracle-god who says a good thing or a bad thing clearly in a single word, and is deified as the deity of the Hitokotonushi Shrine of Gose City in Nara Prefecture.)
